entry.et: Middle English frien, from Anglo-French frire, from Latin frigere to roast; akin to Greek phrygein to roast, fry, Sanskrit bhṛjjati he roasts

def.dt: :to cook in a pan or on a griddle over heat especially with the use of fat
:electrocute 1
:to damage or destroy (an electrical device or its circuitry) by overheating especially as a result of unusually high voltage
:to undergo frying
:to get very hot or burn as if being fried bodies frying on the beach
:a social gathering or picnic where food is fried and eaten a fish fry
:a dish of something fried
:french fry usually used in plural a burger and fries

entry.et: Middle English, Anglo-French frie, from freier, frier to rub, spawn fray

def.dt: :recently hatched or juvenile fishes
:the young of other animals
:very small adult fishes
:members of a group or class :individuals small fry
Christopher 1907–2005 Eng. dram.
:quick bread cooked (as by American Indians) by deep-frying
:a dish or meal of fried food
:to cook in deep fat
:a picnic or supper featuring fried fish
:fried fish
:a strip of potato fried in deep fat usually used in plural
:to fry (as strips of potato) in deep fat until brown
